wpt.name: GC11YAH
wpt.desc: Indian Hannah by SquirtGunn, Traditional Cache (2/1.5)

groundspeak:cache.groundspeak:name: Indian Hannah
groundspeak:cache.groundspeak:long_description:
INDIAN HANNAH (1730 - 1802)
The last of the Indians in Chester County, was born in the vale about 300 yards to the east on the land of the protector of her people the Quaker Assemblyman, William Webb. Her mother was Indian Sarah and her grandmother was Indian Jane.
Their totem: the tortoise. The Lenape creation myth maintains that Kishelemukong, the Creator, brought a turtle up from the ocean. It grew into an island (North America). The first men and women sprouted from a tree on the turtleâ€™s back.
About the time Indian Hannah was born there was an influx of English, Scotch-Irish, and German settlers who ignored colonial land laws protecting Indians. Europeans wanted all the land. Most Lenapes were pushed west to the Susquehanna and Ohio river valleys or died of war and European diseases like smallpox and malaria.
Indian Hannah lived along the Brandwine and made baskets and brooms and sold herbs. She was know as a healer.
___________________________________________________
This area is not plowed in the winter. BYOP

groundspeak:log.groundspeak:text: Quick find with dawnie22 on our way to LG. TFTC
